economic_context.details: Claudon was interrogated with unusual severity about her early life and lack of proper profession. She was extremely poor, living on charity. She had pursued a lawsuit over her 'dolbaire' (unclear what this refers to) against late Demenge Meschi both at Charmes and Nancy. There was tension between beggars - Claudon had been accused by other poor of hindering them from gaining entry to houses by demanding alms for her husband as well as herself. Witness 5 testified to jealousy over alms distribution.

extraction_metadata.notes: This trial provides exceptionally detailed witness testimony with specific quotes in French and clear patterns of quarrel-threat-harm sequences. The economic context is particularly rich, showing tensions among the poor over alms distribution. Claudon initially resisted but eventually confessed voluntarily before torture, then gave additional confessions under torture. The term 'dolbaire' is unclear - possibly a household item or property. Her time in Rome working for Cardinal Rodolphe's household is unusual biographical detail. Devil's mark was found via pricking test. All five accomplices named are from Charmes.
